TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Sandy, mixed Ustic Haplocryolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Bangston sandy loam - timberland.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
Oi--1 to 0 inches; partially decomposed organic material.  Principally from leaves, needles, and grass remains.  (0 to 2 inches thick)
A1--0 to 9 inches; dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) light sandy loam, very dark brown (10YR 2/2) moist; weak fine crumb structure; soft, very friable; neutral (pH 6.8); clear smooth boundary.  (8 to 12 inches thick)
A2--9 to 30 inches; brown (10YR 4/3) loamy sand, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; single grained; soft, very friable; neutral (pH 7.0); gradual smooth boundary.  (8 to 28 inches thick)
C--30 to 60 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) loamy sand, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; single grained; soft, very friable; about 5 percent small sandstone fragments; neutral (pH 6.8).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Mesa County, Colorado; NE 1/4 of Sec. 29, T. 13 S., R.  101 W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  These soils have mollic epipedons ranging in thickness from 16 to 40 inches.  They are noncalcareous throughout and have no bedrock or strongly contrasting substratums above 40 inches.  The estimated organic carbon content ranges from .8 to 2 percent in the mollic epipedon and decreases uniformly with increasing depth.  Typically, conductivity is less than 1 millimho, calcium carbonate equivalent less than 1 percent, and exchangeable sodium percentage less than 1.  The soil is 90 to 100 percent base-saturated.  The 10-to 40- inch control section ranges from sand to loamy sand, excluding loamy very fine sand.  Rock fragments range from 0 to 30 percent but are commonly less than 10 percent.  They consist principally of small sandstone fragments.  Mean annual soil temperature ranges from 32 to 47 degrees F, and mean summer soil temperatures ranges from 46 to 58 degrees F.
The A1 horizon has hue of 10YR, through 7.5YR, value of 4 or 5 dry or 2 or 3 moist, and chroma of 1 through 3.  It is neutral to mildly alkaline and remains relatively constant in reaction with depth.  This horizon is soft to slightly hard.
The C horizon has hue of 2.5Y through 7.5YR 4 or 5 dry, 3 or 4 moist and chrome of 2 through 4.  It is neutral to mildly alkaline and remains relatively constant in reaction with depth.
In New Mexico and Arizona these soils have BA and nondiagnostic cambic horizons which are part of the mollic epipedon and underlying nonalbic 2E horizons which are not.
The 2E horizons have textures of flaggy loamy sand, flaggy loamy fine sand, or loamy sand.  Also present are 2E/BT horizons below 40 inches that have a few, thin lamellae less than 1 cm thick.  Textures are very flaggy loamy sand or very flaggy loamy fine sand with total rock fragment content ranging from 35 to 60 percent in this horizon.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Koppes (ID), Tazlina (T) (AK), and Tomichi (CO) series.  Koppes soils have slightly acid to moderately acid C horizons, expected to have base saturation of 50 to 75 percent.  Tazlina soils have long cold subarctic winters and short warm summers.  Tomichi soils are very pale brown below depth of 7 to 15 inches.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Bangston soils are on upland hills and ridges, usually on toe slopes below areas of sandstone.  Elevation ranges from 8,500 to more than 9,500 feet and slope gradient ranges from 5 to 50 percent.  At the type location, the average annual precipitation is 20 inches.  The mean annual temperature is 38 degrees F and the mean summer temperature is 51 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Skyway soils and the Splitro soils.  Splitro soils have a lithic contact at depths of 10 to 20 inches.  Skyway soils have coarse-loamy control sections and pachic epipedons.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well to somewhat excessively drained; slow runoff; rapid to very rapid permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Bangston soils are used principally as native pastureland.  Principal native plants in the tree cover are aspen, ponderosa pine, Douglas-fir, and Engelmann spruce.  Understory plants are sage, Columbia needlegrass, Colorado blue ryegrass, Thurber fescue, elk sedge, and native bluegrass.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  The western slope of Colorado and northwest New Mexico and northeast Arizona.  The series is of moderate extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Mesa County (Lower Colorado Area), Colorado, 1970.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Differential between Bangston and Tomichi soils need further study.  Pachic soils are not classified in material coarser then loamy very fine sand.  Mollic epipedon is from 0 to 30 inches.  Last updated by the state 11/91.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
